newsitem.title: PAPUA NEW GUINEA: Papua New Guinea police fire tear gas into crowd.
newsitem.headline: Papua New Guinea police fire tear gas into crowd.

text.p: Papua New Guinea police on Wednesday fired tear gas into a crowd of more than 500 people planning to march on the South Pacific nation's parliament in protest at the recent pay-back killing of four school boys.
Several people at the planned march in the capital Port Moresby told reporters police fired tear gas after youths waving placards became restless, wanting to start the march early.
Police fired several tear gas canisters into the crowd which consisted of unemployed youths, schoolboys and women, including the mothers of the murdered boys, local reporters said.
"People ran in all directions," said a woman at the sports oval where the crowd had gathered around 6.00 a.m. (1900 GMT).
"The women, including the mothers of the four students, were caught by the tear gas," a local newspaper photographer at the scene told Reuters. No injuries were reported.

Many schools had been closed to allow students to join the protest march which planned to deliver a petition to parliament calling for an end to the crime wave sweeping the country and for the early arrest of the schoolboys' murder or murderers.
Police told the crowd they would not be allowed to march on the parliament, but the country's police commissioner would meet them to hear their grievances

The four schoolboys were found hacked to death on a beach on the outskirts of Port Moresby last month in what is believed to be a pay-back killing after a man was stabbed to death at a dance in the capital the night before.
Pay-back killings -- often disproportionate to the original crime -- are part of Papua New Guinea tradition.

But the schoolboy killings have shocked the residents of Port Moresby, one of the world's most dangerous cities where wealthier residents live behind high walls, razor-wire and electronic surveillance.

Rising unemployment and urban drift has led to the growth of urban gangs called "rascals" and a spiralling crime rate which has seen numerous shoot-outs in Port Moresby between rascals and police in the past month.
Last Friday a two-month dusk-to-dawn curfew was imposed across this mountainous, resource-rich country in an attempt to curb crime. Police can also impose special daylight curfews.
Police last month gave permission for the protest march, but said on Wednesday they had stopped it under the new curfew laws.
Assistant Police Commissioner Philip Taku said on Wednesday he was considering a gun amnesty to coincide with the curfew.
Taku also said police were checking whether guns used by rascals were of army issue, after claims that some defence force members might be selling arms to the gangs.
He also said police were checking whether marijuana drug runners were bringing arms into the country from Australia, Indonesia and the nearby Solomon Islands.
